description:
Torque teno virus 3 (TTV3) is a small, non-enveloped, circular, single-stranded DNA virus that belongs to the Anelloviridae family. It is classified as a member of the Betatorquevirus genus within this family.

TTV3 is a widely distributed virus that has been detected in various human and animal populations worldwide. The virus is known to infect humans, but its clinical significance is not entirely clear. While some studies have suggested potential associations between TTV3 and certain human diseases, its precise role in human health and disease remains a subject of ongoing research.

Genetically, TTV3 has a relatively small genome, consisting of approximately 3.8 to 3.9 kilobases of DNA. The viral genome encodes multiple open reading frames (ORFs) that are responsible for the production of various viral proteins, including the core structural proteins and proteins involved in viral replication and regulation.

Epidemiological studies have shown that TTV3 infection is common in the general population, with high prevalence rates reported in many countries. The virus is believed to be transmitted through various routes, including fecal-oral, respiratory, and blood-borne routes, although the exact modes of transmission are not fully understood.

Overall, Torque teno virus 3 is an intriguing member of the Anelloviridae family, and continued research is needed to elucidate its potential clinical significance and its role in human health and disease.
